title-group.article-title: Book Review: Teaching able, gifted and talented children: Strategies, activities, resources

contrib.aff: Director: TASC International, UK, ISBN 978-1-4129-4766-4 144 pps

article-meta.issue-title: Special issue: New technologies and virtual learning
article-meta.product: TunnicliffeClive, Teaching able, gifted and talented children: Strategies, activities, resources, Sage Publications Ltd (2010)

body.p: There is now a wealth of material available with regard to the education of able, gifted and talented learners. The aim of the author is to provide a concise summary of what is known about the definition, identification and provision for those pupils who learn at a faster rate than others. Tunnicliffe suggests that the reader turns immediately to the final section – the bibliography – and then identifies the relevant areas of interest and concern.
The book summarizes considerations with regard to:

list-item.p: developing a whole-school policy and an enabling school ethos;
Defining and supporting a coherent teaching-learning policy;
selecting and using a wide variety of identification procedures;
organizing and implementing personalized learning procedures;
reflecting on various procedures for classroom practice; and
establishing an extra-curricular programme of activities.

body.p: The appendix provides a list of useful websites, agencies and associations.
The text is well organized with icons indicating the chapter objectives, activities and case studies, and points for reflection.

The book is, indeed, a useful summary of key issues in the field of ‘gifted’ education, and the discerning reader will identify his or her own particular areas of interest and reflection. Schools will be able to identify those issues with which they are already dealing, and those issues which might need closer attention.
